results.content:
Está muy bien, explica las cosas bien y te permite iniciarte en un mundo complicado donde muchas veces los que más cuestan son los primeros pasos. Por el precio que tiene está francamente bien. Hay otros recursos gratuitos, pero sinceramente, un curso de pago garantiza un orden, respuestas, etc. que merece la pena, porque recibes algo de mucho valor.

El único problema serio que veo es que está obsoleto en algunas cosas importantes, como la declaración de variables, y creo que en cierto modo, hacer un video que explique "donde ponemos let ahora es var" ahorraría muchos problemas. Todos entendemos que la programación evoluciona, y sería interesante un video de "lo que ha cambiado" desde entonces. 

Como team menor, los subtítulos deben ser reales, no sé si es una máquina o qué pero dicen cosas aberrantes a veces. 

En general, satisfecho.

results.content: You should talk slower, and more sure of what you want to say. It is sometimes hard to follow, because you did not rehearse enough. Please re-record sections where you are lost for words. Try using shorter sentences. Use simple statements and avoid the word "because"; You are a trainer, we trust you to know what you are talking about. Try using more dynamic emphasis. When listening to your diction, it seems that every single thing is equally important. That does not make it easy to follow. People's minds wander, and your mode of speech requires 100% attention 100% of the time. That is tiring, and can be improved by speaking quietly into a more sensitive microphone, and by being very aware of where you are using emphasis, and why. This skill can be picked up quickly, when tutoring classrooms.

results.content: This course is a good introduction to the Three,js library. I do think it needs updating. You can do about 85% of the lectures with the current Three.js code, however, there are a few lectures that are outdated. If you get stuck, or get errors while following the lecture, look at the course questions section. Some people, including myself, have posted solutions to depreciated code or methods. Other than that, this is a pretty good course.
results.content_html: This course is a good introduction to the Three,js library. I do think it needs updating. You can do about 85% of the lectures with the current Three.js code, however, there are a few lectures that are outdated. If you get stuck, or get errors while following the lecture, look at the course questions section. Some people, including myself, have posted solutions to depreciated code or methods. Other than that, this is a pretty good course.

results.content: Very beautifully structured course for beginners who are starting to learn 3D concepts.
results.content_html: Very beautifully structured course for beginners who are starting to learn 3D concepts.

results.content: The challenges are good and this course gives a solid introduction to basic concepts, but it really suffers from what feels like some messy/non-standard javascript and programming on the instructor's part, as well as some messy cuts/tricky pacing. The instructor sometimes uses some techniques/classes no longer supported by the three.js API and generally seems to use some questionable techniques for implementing the projects, which leaves me wondering whether what we're being taught here is all best-practice or not.
results.content_html: The challenges are good and this course gives a solid introduction to basic concepts, but it really suffers from what feels like some messy/non-standard javascript and programming on the instructor's part, as well as some messy cuts/tricky pacing. The instructor sometimes uses some techniques/classes no longer supported by the three.js API and generally seems to use some questionable techniques for implementing the projects, which leaves me wondering whether what we're being taught here is all best-practice or not.

results.content:
The course seems good.
But the accent seriously needs improvement. I know it's not your native language, but the students at least need to understand the technical terms. Using the subtitles was the only other option but since that's auto-generated was not useful at all. Adding them would help a lot.
Another major point to note is that displaying a pre-existing code won't help a student. He can get that from StackOverflow.
I would suggest writing it as the course goes along while explaining the reason for it. That would make it more impactful.
results.content_html:

results.content: The teacher's choice of words and sentences provide very concise knowledge transfer.  He also explains every aspect of the code in a consistent pace that allows you to "get it" quicker and more completely.  You need to have some JavaScript chops, but even if you don't, you can code along with him and produce the results you see him doing. And, in a project using THREE.js, you will know where things are so you can debug and tweak.
results.content_html: The teacher's choice of words and sentences provide very concise knowledge transfer. He also explains every aspect of the code in a consistent pace that allows you to "get it" quicker and more completely. You need to have some JavaScript chops, but even if you don't, you can code along with him and produce the results you see him doing. And, in a project using THREE.js, you will know where things are so you can debug and tweak.

You will need to go over the provided resources to get much of the code working.

results.content:
Covering topics like basic geometry?  It looks like an attempt just to pad your hours.  Absolutely unrelated except to the extremely uneducated.  I lost interest very fast in this course...

Also you barely cover the topics of importation.  There are plenty of vector files to pull in and really take your three.js to a high lvl.  You only cover one of them... extremely simplistically.

There are free resources that cover more in depth and more to the point than this class.

response.content:
Thanks for the review,
In my experience there are enough programmers who doesn't remember geometry and math, you can always skip those parts. It seems that you already know Three.js, so I wonder why did you took the course, obviously the basic terms don't interest you, the coding exercises don't challenge you and the examples are too simple for you... I do think this course gives much more value than other free or paid resources I know.

There are free resources that cover more in depth and more to the point than this class.

results.content:
I got very comfortable, very quickly.
almost every exercise is the perfect seed for more personal exploration.
i immediately was able to program new and unique things on my own.  
i like how straightforward he is.
the information is organized very well, ie, powerpoint definitions, graphics, examples, then code and explanation of code.  
I'm inspired to program my own ideas now, thank you Shay!
results.content_html:
I got very comfortable, very quickly.
almost every exercise is the perfect seed for more personal exploration.
i immediately was able to program new and unique things on my own.
i like how straightforward he is.
the information is organized very well, ie, powerpoint definitions, graphics, examples, then code and explanation of code.
I'm inspired to program my own ideas now, thank you Shay!

results.content: The course met my expectations. The instructor provided relevant information and delivered his instruction in a clear and effective manner. I felt that the instructor may improve his navigation through the material. An example is not showing the code to add a light to a scene, then showing what the student should expect to see, which they can't because the light hasn't been added yet, then going back and adding the light afterwards. This is the only thing that I think might be improved upon.

This is the only thing that I think might be improved upon.

results.content:
It is the best course that I have made by Udemy. I appreciated much that Tim took several examples, each of them ending with a solution at the end of the chapter. I hate course that have just one project all over the course. Further on I liked Tim´s handling with a basic JavaScript-Layout with always the same seperation into the main and init function. So it makes fun working with a template.
The only thing that did not work were no responses for my questions!!
But nevertheless I give Tim 5 points!!

results.content: Overall this was a solid way to learn three.js! I docked half a star due to a few things being outdated in the library and a few instances where the instructor's accent made steps difficult to follow along. I would recommend this to others looking to learn three.js. Great work!
results.content_html: Overall this was a solid way to learn three.js! I docked half a star due to a few things being outdated in the library and a few instances where the instructor's accent made steps difficult to follow along. I would recommend this to others looking to learn three.js. Great work!

results.content: I learned a lot about three.js from this course, but I thought the presentation could have been a little better. A lot of courses on Udemy take the approach of providing the starting template for a lecture and then you follow along by typing in as they type and describe what is going on, which adds interactivity. However, in most of this course the final file and the code is just described which got a little boring at times. Most of the exercises were fun to do, except exercise 4, which required knowledge we hadn't been shown yet. Some of the content is out of date now with the latest version of three.js so you will need to look in the Q&A to figure out why the examples are not working.
results.content_html: I learned a lot about three.js from this course, but I thought the presentation could have been a little better. A lot of courses on Udemy take the approach of providing the starting template for a lecture and then you follow along by typing in as they type and describe what is going on, which adds interactivity. However, in most of this course the final file and the code is just described which got a little boring at times. Most of the exercises were fun to do, except exercise 4, which required knowledge we hadn't been shown yet. Some of the content is out of date now with the latest version of three.js so you will need to look in the Q&A to figure out why the examples are not working.

results.content: I have been looking for a detailed tutorial for three.js and I can't believe I didn't look on Udemy first. This class was exactly what I was looking for. I could tell I was in the right place when one of the first lectures was reviewing vector math. This was the detail that I needed as a three.js beginner. Thank you so much for this great course!

results.content: It's a good starting point, but I don't see how I would work only with geometrical shapes in real life, would be useful to have a few lessons also on how to import and position external 3D models, how to move them etc.

results.content:
Shay is super good in teaching! He makes a recap every some lessons. I had some problems with the diamond explosion exercise but you have just to take the time to learn. I don't give up and i go straight with this course. I tried many three.js courses here in Udemy but this is the best for a noob like me and the english he uses is not so complicated to understand or fast. Thanks a lot Shy!
PS: I'm sorry for my bad english but i'm still studying it, i'm from Italy :D

This course helped my company and me to reduce the development time of one new functionality from a planed three months to three weeks.
Thanks, Shay! Thanks, Tim!,

results.content:
I am at around 80% of the course so it is fair to cast a review now. This is an introductory course on Three JS WebGL library

Beginning with the Critical Review: 
The accent of the instructor is very thick and hard to  be understood. Pronunciation is terrible. He say sometimes phrases that do not mean anything in English but you can manage to understand from the context. I know this is difficult to improve. I am not a native speaker. I suggest adding subtitles if they do not exist and improve a little bit if possible the pronunciation if possible.

Some sections  mainly the introductory videos which mentions few parts than what is actually presented), probably this because the instructor added sections after introductory videos was shot- That is fine!)

What is not fine is the cutting suddenly of the video when a mistake is made and then patching it again. it is so annoying (I realize he is using Camtasia Video recording. This should not happen with right editing) Probably on next iteration of the course it would amazing if these would be addressed

Concerning what is positive: 
The skills of the instructor are very good. He is knowledgeable and you can enjoy  generally speaking the course and learn a lot from the course. You have to be knowledgeable in JavaScript 2016 ECMAScript version of course to take this course.

I hope if the instructor is reading my comments that he adds more sections on multiplayer games in Three JS, and maybe a little bit about VR/AR etc... or create a separate course that is more advanced, we are happy to buy it. WebGL (three js, Babylon js ....) and WebVR  and AR API on the web are in great demand these days!
results.content_html:
I am at around 80% of the course so it is fair to cast a review now. This is an introductory course on Three JS WebGL library

Beginning with the Critical Review:
The accent of the instructor is very thick and hard to be understood. Pronunciation is terrible. He say sometimes phrases that do not mean anything in English but you can manage to understand from the context. I know this is difficult to improve. I am not a native speaker. I suggest adding subtitles if they do not exist and improve a little bit if possible the pronunciation if possible.

Some sections mainly the introductory videos which mentions few parts than what is actually presented), probably this because the instructor added sections after introductory videos was shot- That is fine!)

What is not fine is the cutting suddenly of the video when a mistake is made and then patching it again. it is so annoying (I realize he is using Camtasia Video recording. This should not happen with right editing) Probably on next iteration of the course it would amazing if these would be addressed

Concerning what is positive:
The skills of the instructor are very good. He is knowledgeable and you can enjoy generally speaking the course and learn a lot from the course. You have to be knowledgeable in JavaScript 2016 ECMAScript version of course to take this course.

I hope if the instructor is reading my comments that he adds more sections on multiplayer games in Three JS, and maybe a little bit about VR/AR etc... or create a separate course that is more advanced, we are happy to buy it. WebGL (three js, Babylon js ....) and WebVR and AR API on the web are in great demand these days!
